content: alberta sunshine by sandra buzza this is a lightweight version of alberta summer that s perfect for sunny days it can be made with any fingering weight yarn or a marled effect can be achieved with two strands of lace weight held together it has a classic t-shirt fit with about 2 inches of positive ease and a hem that hits at mid hip the lace pattern at the yoke is a variation of the one in alberta summer but is more open and has the option to be knit with just a single strand of lace weight yarn for a more delicate effect the orange sample was made with two strand of lace yarn held together and a single strand in the lace at the yoke this is a good project for a beginner sweater knitter as the lace is very simple and there s minimal shaping german short row are used to lower the front neckline materials yarn approximately 720 800 880 960 1060 m of fingering weight yarn double these amounts if using lace weight is held double more yarn is required to lengthen either the body or the sleeves needle 3 25mm us 3 circular needle for the ribbing and a 3 5mm us 4 circular needle for the body of the sweater you can vary the wire length to accommodate the number of stitches or use a longer wire and use magic looping for the sleeves and neckline gauge 25 5 sts and 36 row for 4 or 10 cm in stockinette after blocking sizes xs s m l xl giving a finished chest measurement of 35 5 40 43 46 50 the body measures 14 or 35 cm for all sizes from the underarm but can be easily adjusted the sleeves measured 2 or 5 cm for all sizes from the underarm but can be easily lengthened german short row german short row are used the raise the back neckline and lower the back hemline in this sweater they are indicated in the pattern by the term ds which stands for double stitch to do this right side work to the stitch specified in your pattern and turn the work so the wrong side is facing slip the first stitch on the left needle to the right needle purlwise with yarn in front pull the yarn to the back of the work over top of the right needle this will distort the stitch making it look as if there are 2 stitches instead of 1 bring the yarn to the front again between the needles to begin purling make sure to keep firm gauge on this double stitch when purling the next stitch wrong side purl to the stitch indicated by the pattern and turn the work so the right side is facing bring the yarn to the front between the needle and slip the first stitch from the left needle to the right needle purlwise with the yarn in front pull the yarn
